Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Power Generation from Fluid-Structure Interaction using Mathematical, Computational, and Experimental Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merits: The interaction of a flowing fluid and a deformable structure or solid is one of the richest sources of mathematical challenges and fundamental physical phenomena with important applications to engineering and technology including energy harvesting and power generation. The physical phenomena of interest range from blood flows in arteries, to airflow over an oscillating tongue that can lead to clinical dangerous and potentially fatal oscillations, to flow over flexible long span bridges and tall buildings, to flow over and around flight vehicles over a wide range of scales from micro air vehicles to modern passenger airliners, to fluid-structural systems whose limit cycles may be a source of energy harvesting and power generation. It is this last application that motivates much of the proposed work. While in many applications the concern is that the limit cycle oscillations will damage the mechanical integrity of the fluid/structural system, in the energy harvesting and power generation application these oscillations will be both novel and beneficial.
The methods that have been proposed to better understand and exploit these phenomena include theoretical models of high sophistication including the continuum models of the fluid and the structure. While analytical solutions continue to be sought and found, computational models that tax the resources of the most powerful computers also play an important role, as do scale model experiments based upon a sound fundamental analysis and understanding of the first principles of the relevant continuum models. Indeed, it is by exploiting the complementary strengths of each approach theoretical modeling, computational modeling, and experimental scale models that the deepest and richest insights can be obtained.

Broader Impact: This proposal brings together senior investigators from three major research institutions covering a wide range of intellectual experience from modern mathematics to rigorously based computational models to multidisciplinary experiments to address fluid-structure interaction phenomena. This research will also provide an opportunity for graduate students and post-doctoral visitors to participate and learn in this rich environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaborative research effort between senior researchers at UCLA, Duke, and Georgia Tech to study Fluid Structure Interaction (FSI) in flexible structures subject to axial flow. In the case of normal flow systems, such as aircraft wings, bridges, and tall buildings, aeroelastic flutter is usually undesirable and can often lead to catastrophic failure. In contrast, the axial flow system considered in this project, a low wind speed energy harvester, serves a useful purpose as a result of being subjected to flutter. With the use of piezoelectric materials, a beam-like structure fluttering in the wind, much in the way that a flag does, can output useable electrical energy.

 

The primary goal of this project was to develop a mathematically rich, yet implementable, continuum theory for aeroelasticity in axial flow. From a mathematical standpoint, modeling fluid-structure interaction in axial flow is substantially more complex than in normal flow. The key difference is that the axial flow case requires the solution of the Generalized Possio Integral Equation (GPIE), a 2-D form of the 1-D Possio Integral Equation encountered in normal flow. Over the duration of this project, the GPIE and the equations for aeroelastic bending and torsion dynamics were solved, and theoretical findings were made based on the mathematical solutions. For example, it was found that torsional motion is unconditionally stable for inviscid, incompressible flow and linear structure dynamics.

 

In addition to modeling the system and solving the equations, the research at UCLA consisted of developing techniques to implement the continuum theory in a computer program to predict the flutter speed in axial flow systems. One challenge involved the fact that in the axial flow case certain functions are only defined for non-negative arguments, and as a result the stability analysis was reformulated. Additionally, a significant amount of effort was placed in developing techniques to evaluate singular integrals, i.e. integrals where the integrand is infinite at one or more points within the domain. Finally, numerical integration and root-finding methods were employed to calculate the flutter speed, and comparisons were made to experimental data.

 

The secondary goal of this project was to explore possible designs of axial flow piezoelectric energy harvesting devices. It was found that the flutter speed for plastic structures is much lower than their metal counterparts, making them more suitable for a wind power application while providing sufficient durability. It was also observed, through wind tunnel experiments, that the piezoelectric material can generate power and withstand the strain from the fluttering structure when cantilevered at the clamped end of the structure. Finally, through a no-cost time extension, theoretical efforts were undertaken to investigate nonlinear structure effects in axial flow aeroelasticity, the results of which will be presented in the final project report.
